paper_metadata.title: Theory and research in strategic management: Swings of a pendulum
paper_metadata.research_context: A historical and thematic review of the development of the strategic management field, tracing theoretical and methodological shifts (e.g., IO economics, organizational economics, resource-based view, knowledge-based view, transaction costs, agency theory, strategic leadership) and discussing future directions.

core_theories.name: resource-based view
core_theories.grounding_phrase: Based on the resource-based view or developing concurrently were research on strategic leadership, strategic decision theory (process research) and knowledge-based view of the ﬁrm.
core_theories.evidence: The paper emphasizes the rise of the resource-based view (RBV) as a dominant framework in the 1980s and 1990s and attributes a refocusing on firms' internal strengths and resources to RBV (e.g., Barney, 1991; Wernerfelt, 1984).

core_theories.name: industrial organization economics
core_theories.grounding_phrase: Perhaps, one of the more signiﬁcant contributions to the development of strategic management came from industrial organization (IO) economics, speciﬁcally the work of Michael Porter.
core_theories.evidence: The paper describes the adoption of the structure-conduct-performance paradigm and Porter's Five Forces as central IO contributions that shifted attention to industry structure and competitive position.

core_theories.name: transaction costs economics
core_theories.grounding_phrase: the ﬁeld began to emphasize transaction costs analysis (Williamson, 1975, 1985), which examines the ﬁrm-environment interface through a contractual or exchange-based approach.
core_theories.evidence: The review links TCE to research on firm boundaries, markets versus hierarchies, the adoption of multidivisional structures, vertical integration, and alliances.

core_theories.name: agency theory
core_theories.grounding_phrase: the organizational economics perspective contributed transaction costs economics and agency theory to strategic management.
core_theories.evidence: The paper describes agency theory's focus on separation of ownership and control, managerial opportunism, governance mechanisms (boards, ownership, compensation), and applications to diversification, corporate governance, and innovation.

core_theories.name: knowledge-based view
core_theories.evidence: The review presents the KBV as an extension of RBV that emphasizes tacit and social knowledge (Polanyi), absorptive capacity, and organizational learning as drivers of competitive advantage.

core_theories.name: strategic leadership
core_theories.evidence: The paper highlights strategic leadership and upper echelon perspectives (e.g., Hambrick & Mason) as important substreams tied to RBV and the study of firm heterogeneity, managerial discretion, and decision processes.

coverage_report.reason: This paper is a conceptual/review article that does not contain numbered hypotheses or propositions tied to empirical tests. Per the extraction scope, core constructs and relationships are only extracted when explicitly tied to Hypotheses/Propositions or to empirical tests; none were present. Core theories grounding the review's central claims were extracted instead.
